content: The "Anna Westin Act of 2015" includes sections on short title, table of contents, findings, definitions, training and education, public service announcements, and clarification of existing parity law. The Congress finds that anorexia nervosa increases the risk of death by 18 times compared to individuals without the disorder. It is estimated that one person dies every 62 minutes from an eating disorder, with significant health consequences such as osteoporosis, gastrointestinal issues, cardiac problems, and dental issues. Approximately 14,500,000 people in the United States suffer from eating disorders. Eating disorders affect a significant number of people in the United States, with 14,500,000 individuals estimated to be suffering from them. These disorders, which include anorexia nervosa, are treatable biopsychosocial illnesses with high rates of comorbidity with other conditions like depression and substance abuse. Anorexia nervosa is an eating disorder characterized by self-starvation, weight loss, fear of gaining weight, and serious health consequences including heart failure, kidney failure, osteoporosis, and death. People with anorexia nervosa are 57 times more likely to die of suicide than their peers. Bulimia nervosa has a lifetime prevalence between 0.9-1.5% among women and 0.1-0.5% among men. Bulimia nervosa has a lifetime prevalence of 0.9-1.5% among women and 0.1-0.5% among men, with serious health consequences such as cardiac, gastrointestinal, and dental problems. Binge eating disorder is characterized by frequent episodes of uncontrolled overeating, affecting 3.5% of women and 2.0% of men in the United States. Binge eating disorder affects 3.5% of women and 2.0% of men in the United States, leading to various health risks such as obesity, high blood pressure, elevated cholesterol levels, and increased risk of diabetes and cancers. Many individuals experience some symptoms of anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, or binge eating disorder. Between 4-20% of young women engage in unhealthy dieting, purging, and binge eating behaviors, with rates of eating disorders being similar in men and women. Academic evidence shows a link between using very thin models in advertising and consumer attitudes towards brands, as well as the influence of these models on consumer behavior. Eating disorders affect all demographics in the US and are linked to psychological issues like depression and substance abuse. Hospitalizations for eating disorders in children under 12 rose by 119% between 1999 and 2006. The Act defines "eating disorder" to include various conditions like anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Act also addresses training and education. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, shall revise and reinstate the BodyWise Handbook of the Department of Education to include updated information on eating disorders for males and females. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, shall update the BodyWise Handbook with information on eating disorders for males and females, incorporate it into the BodyWorks obesity prevention program, and make it publicly available. The BodyWise Handbook and related resources, along with the BodyWorks obesity prevention program, are available for free to educate universities and nonprofit entities on eating disorders. SEC. 6. EDUCATION AND TRAINING FOR HEALTH PROFESSIONALS. The Secretary will award grants to integrate training on eating disorders and treatment levels for health professionals. The Secretary will award grants for training on eating disorders and treatment levels for health professionals, including patient referral, prevention of eating disorders, and treatment methods. Entities seeking grants must submit an application outlining fund usage and training evaluation. Entities receiving grants under this section must develop a training program on evidence-based findings, best practices, and recommendations for eating disorder identification, prevention, and treatment. The funds should be used for educational training, including Internet-based courses and teleconferences. Entities receiving grants under this section must develop a training program on evidence-based findings, best practices, and recommendations for eating disorder identification, prevention, and treatment. The training may include Internet-based courses and teleconferences on preventing eating disorders, identifying individuals at risk, and conducting comprehensive assessments. The training program funded by grants focuses on identifying and treating eating disorders, including conducting assessments and developing treatment plans. The effectiveness of the training in increasing knowledge and changing behaviors will be evaluated and reported to the Secretary. SEC. 7. EDUCATION AND TRAINING FOR SCHOOL AND HIGHER EDUCATION PROFESSIONALS. The Secretary will award grants to conduct educational seminars for school personnel on early identification, intervention, and prevention of behaviors associated with eating disorders, as well as provide resources to individuals affected by eating disorders. Eligible entities must agree to conduct educational seminars as a condition for receiving the grant. As a condition for receiving a grant, eligible entities must conduct educational seminars on eating disorders, using materials from the BodyWise initiative and relevant research. Eligible entities include states, territories, tribes, and organizations. Eligible entities for grants include the District of Columbia, Indian tribes, tribal organizations, and educational institutions. SEC. 8. PUBLIC SERVICE ANNOUNCEMENTS. The Director of the National Institute of Mental Health will conduct public service announcements to educate the public on various aspects of eating disorders, including types, seriousness, identification, intervention, prevention, discrimination, bullying, and the effects of media on self-esteem and body image. The Director of the National Institute of Mental Health will collaborate with centers of excellence and community-based national nonprofit resources to address disordered behaviors, discrimination, bullying, media effects on self-esteem, body image, and signs of eating disorders. SEC. 9. CLARIFYING APPLICATION OF EXISTING PARITY LAW. Section 2726 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include the treatment of permanent exclusions under mental health and substance use disorder benefits in group health plans or health insurance coverage. Section 2726 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include the treatment of permanent exclusions under mental health and substance use disorder benefits in group health plans or health insurance coverage. This includes residential treatment for mental health and substance use disorders. Amendments to ERISA also address these benefits, prohibiting permanent exclusions for specific conditions or disorders. The Act of 1974 is amended to address permanent exclusions under mental health and substance use disorder benefits in group health plans or health insurance coverage. This includes prohibiting permanent exclusions for these benefits. The Act of 1974 is amended to address permanent exclusions under mental health and substance use disorder benefits in group health plans or health insurance coverage, prohibiting permanent exclusions for these benefits. Additionally, mental health and substance use disorder benefits now include residential treatment. The Act of 1974 is amended to prohibit permanent exclusions for mental health and substance use disorder benefits in group health plans. Additionally, residential treatment is now included in these benefits. The Act of 1974 is amended to include residential treatment in mental health and substance use disorder benefits under group health plans. This does not expand the scope of services already covered under existing laws. No additional funds are authorized for this Act or its amendments; existing funds will be used instead.
